CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: Significant progress has been made in synthesis of conjugated polymers and their applications for optoelectronic device such as organic light - emitting diodes ( OLEDs ) , organic photovoltaic cells ( OPVs ) , and organic field - effect transistors ( OFETs ) since Heeger , MacDiarmid , and Shirakawa discovered conducting polymers in 1976.^1 As a result of the low - cost , light - weight , and flexibility advantages , optoelectronic devices based on conjugated polymers are a promising cost - effective alternative to inorganic materials - based microelectronics. Conjugated polymers can be classified as hole ( p - type ) or electron ( n - type ) transporting materials according to the type of orderly transferring charge carriers. Most of conjugated polymers are p - type semiconductors that have seen a dramatic rise in performance over the past decade while much less attention has been devoted to n - type semiconducting polymers that have lagged behind their p - type counterparts. 2 Organic n - type materials are essential for the fabrication of organic p-n junctions , OPVs , n-channel OFETs , OLEDs , and complementary logic circuits. 3 The n - type building blocks are the core components in n - type semiconducting polymers. Aromatic imides such as rylene diimides are one of the classical n - type building blocks and can exhibit relatively high electron affinities , high electron mobilities , and excellent chemical , thermal , and photochemical stabilities. 4 These materials are electron deficient due to the substitution of an aromatic core with one or two sets of π-accepting imide groups that are mutually conjugated. The widely used rylene diimides include perylene diimides ( PDIs , 1 ) and naphthalene diimides ( NDIs , 2 ) ( Figure 1 ). Zhan and co-workers reported the synthesis of the first soluble rylene-based fully conjugated polymer. 5 Top-gate OFETs based on this PDI- dithienothiophene copolymer exhibited a saturation electron mobility ( μ e ) of 6 x 10^-2 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 , current on / off ratio ( I on / I off ) of 10^4 , and a low threshold voltage ( V th ) of 7 V in air. 6 Moreover , all - polymer solar cells based on blends of polythiophene derivative donors and PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer acceptors exhibited power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) as high as 1.5% ( AM1.5 , 100 mW cm^-2 ). 7-9 Facchetti et al. reported a conjugated copolymer of NDI and bithiophene ; 10 OFET devices based on this polymer fabricated in a top-gate , bottom - contact configuration with polymeric dielectrics exhibited μ e of 0.1-0.85 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 under ambient conditions with I on / I off > 10^5 . 11 The simplest aromatic imide system is phthalimide ( 3 ) and thiophene imide ( 4 ) ( Figure 1 ). A few literatures reported phthalimide - containing conjugated polymers such as poly-(phenylene ethynylene)s , 12 a polyaniline derivative , 13 and a polythiophene derivative.

Let's think step by step.

Sure! Let's identify the "Material Name" entities in the paragraph. I will present the valid entities in a Markdown table with one column "Material Name". Here are the entities in the paragraph:

| Material Name |
| --- |
| Conjugated polymers |
| Organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs) |
| Organic photovoltaic cells (OPVs) |
| Organic field-effect transistors (OFETs) |
| Perylene diimides (PDIs) |
| Naphthalene diimides (NDIs) |
| Rylene diimides |
| Polythiophene derivative |
| Bithiophene |
| Phthalimide |
| Thiophene imide |
| Poly(phenylene ethynylene)s |
| Polyaniline derivative |
| Polythiophene derivative |

Note that some of these entities are mentioned multiple times in the paragraph, but I have listed them only once in the table.

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Material name" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Of course! Here are the valid entities in the paragraph that refer to "Material name":

| Material Name |
| --- |
| Conjugated polymers |
| Perylene diimides (PDIs) |
| Naphthalene diimides (NDIs) |
| Rylene diimides |

| Bithiophene |

Sure! Let's identify the values of material properties in the paragraph. I will present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Value". Here is the table:

| Property Value |
| --- |
| 1976 | (Year of discovery of conducting polymers by Heeger, MacDiarmid, and Shirakawa) |
| low-cost | (Advantage of optoelectronic devices based on conjugated polymers) |
| light-weight | (Advantage of optoelectronic devices based on conjugated polymers) |
| flexibility | (Advantage of optoelectronic devices based on conjugated polymers) |
| 10^-2 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 | (Saturation electron mobility of top-gate OFETs based on PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer) |
| 10^4 | (Current on/off ratio of top-gate OFETs based on PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer) |
| 7 V | (Threshold voltage of top-gate OFETs based on PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer in air) |
| 1.5% | (Power conversion efficiency of all-polymer solar cells based on blends of polythiophene derivative donors and PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer acceptors) |
| 0.1-0.85 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 | (Electron mobility of OFETs based on NDI and bithiophene copolymer under ambient conditions) |
| 10^5 | (Current on/off ratio of OFETs based on NDI and bithiophene copolymer under ambient conditions) |
| 7 | (Threshold voltage of OFETs based on NDI and bithiophene copolymer under ambient conditions) |
| 3 | (Year of reporting the synthesis of the first soluble rylene-based fully conjugated polymer) |
| 100 mW cm^-2 | (Power density of the solar cells based on blends of polythiophene derivative donors and PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer acceptors) |
| 1 | (Reference to the first soluble rylene-based fully conjugated polymer) |
| 2 | (Reference to the naphthalene diimides) |
| 5 | (Reference to the synthesis of the first soluble rylene-based fully conjugated polymer) |
| 6 | (Reference to the top-gate OFETs based on PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer) |
| 7 | (Reference to the all-polymer solar cells based on blends of polythiophene derivative donors and PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer acceptors) |
| 9 | (Reference to the Facchetti et al. report on conjugated copolymers of NDI and bithiophene) |
| 11 | (Reference to the OFET devices based on NDI and bithiophene copolymer fabricated in a top-gate, bottom-contact configuration with polymeric dielectrics) |
| 12 | (Reference to the poly(phenylene ethynylene)s) |
| 13 | (Reference to the polyaniline derivative) |
| 14 | (Reference to the polythiophene derivative) |
